SUMMARY: Catabolite repressor activator, Cra, which was initially named Fructose repressor, FruR, is a dual transcriptional regulator that plays a pleiotropic role to modulate direction of carbon flow through different metabolic pathways of energy metabolism, but independently of CRP regulator [9084760, 8577250, 8230205, 18648770]. For this reason FruR regulator is implicated in expression of a large number of operons that encode enzymes which comprise central pathways of carbon metabolism. FruR acts as an activator of genes encoding gluconeogenic [8550429, 8577250, 2496106, 9084760, 3542978] Krebs cycle [16415587, 9084760] and glyoxylate shunt [8195118, 16415587, 9084760] enzymes, and negative effect on genes encoding Entner-Doudoroff pathway [9084760, 18648770]and glycolytic enzymes [8550429, 8577250, 9084760]. Cra carries out a glycolytic flux-dependent regulation. glycolytic flux is determined by concentration of metabolite fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, which is molecular effector of Cra [23277571]. FruR forms a complex with DNA in absence of fructose 1-phosphate or fructose 1,6-phosphate, binding to an 18-bp-long sequence with an imperfect palindromic sequence [9084760, 16115199, 8195118, 8577250, 8858581]. In presence of glucose it increases intracellular concentration of metabolites d-fructose 1-phosphate and d-fructose 1,6-phosphate, which interact with FruR to prevent its binding or displacement of target operons [8230205, 8577250, 8550429]. FruR is inactivated upon interaction of inducers. FruR has been observed to be predominantly a tetrameric structure in solution [8195118]. FruR belongs to GalR-LacI family of transcriptional regulators, which are helix-turn-helix DNA-binding proteins [1805309, 1639817, 2198273]. As a member of this family FruR contains two functional domains: an N-terminal domain which contains a helix-turn-helix motif for DNA binding, and effector binding domain located in C terminus, which is homologous to periplasmic sugar-binding protein for ribose, arabinose, and galactose. deletion of fruR gene causes a reduction in cellular growth. This effect could be due to inhibition of osmoprotectant producing genes, betA, betB, and betT [21718532].
